sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• do not substitute extended-release niacin for equivalent does of immediate-release niacin; initiate niacin with low doses and titrate to desired therapeutic response
  • equivalent doses of niacin extended-release 500-mg tablets and niacin extended-release 1000-mg tablet are interchangeable; however, equivalent doses of niacin extended-release 500-mg tablets and niacin extended-release 750-mg tablets are not interchangeable
  • Coronary arteriosclerosis, in combination with a bile acid binding resin - Hyperlipidemia: (extended-release) initial, 500 mg ORALLY once daily at bedtime; titrate in 500-mg intervals every 4 weeks based on tolerability and efficacy; MAX 2000 mg/day
  • Coronary arteriosclerosis, in combination with a bile acid binding resin - Hyperlipidemia: (extended-release) maintenance, 1000 to 2000 mg ORALLY once daily; MAX 2000 mg/day
  • Dyslipidemia, Mixed - Primary hypercholesterolemia: (immediate-release), initial 250 mg ORALLY once daily; titrate every 4 to 7 days to 1.5 to 2 g ORALLY daily in divided doses; if after 2 months at this dose hyperlipidemia is not adequately controlled, increase at 2- to 4-week intervals to 3 g/day ORALLY in divided doses
  • Dyslipidemia, Mixed - Primary hypercholesterolemia: (immediate-release) maintenance, 1 to 2 g ORALLY 2 to 3 times daily; MAX 6 g/day
  • Dyslipidemia, Mixed - Primary hypercholesterolemia: (extended-release) initial, 500 mg ORALLY once daily at bedtime; titrate in 500-mg intervals every 4 weeks based on tolerability and efficacy; MAX 2000 mg/day
  • Dyslipidemia, Mixed - Primary hypercholesterolemia: (extended-release) maintenance, 1000 to 2000 mg ORALLY once daily; MAX 2000 mg/day
  • Hypertriglyceridemia, severe: (immediate-release), initial 250 mg ORALLY once daily; titrate every 4 to 7 days to 1.5 to 2 g ORALLY daily in divided doses; if after 2 months at this dose hyperlipidemia is not adequately controlled, increase at 2- to 4-week intervals to 3 g/day ORALLY in divided doses
  • Hypertriglyceridemia, severe: (immediate-release) maintenance, 1 to 2 g ORALLY 2 to 3 times daily; MAX 6 g/day
  • Hypertriglyceridemia, severe: (extended-release) initial, 500 mg ORALLY once daily at bedtime; titrate in 500-mg intervals every 4 weeks based on tolerability and efficacy; MAX 2000 mg/day
  • Hypertriglyceridemia, severe: (extended-release) maintenance, 1000 to 2000 mg ORALLY once daily; MAX 2000 mg/day
  • Myocardial infarction, In patients with a history of myocardial infarction and hyperlipidemia; Prophylaxis: (extended-release) initial, 500 mg ORALLY once daily at bedtime; titrate in 500-mg intervals every 4 weeks based on tolerability and efficacy; MAX 2000 mg/day
  • Myocardial infarction, In patients with a history of myocardial infarction and hyperlipidemia; Prophylaxis: (extended-release) maintenance, 1000 to 2000 mg ORALLY once daily; MAX 2000 mg/day
  • Pellagra: 150 to 500 mg ORALLY in divided doses daily (based on case series)
  • Recommended dietary allowance: men, 16 mg/day ORALLY; women, 14 mg/day ORALLY

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• safety and effectiveness of immediate-release tablets have not been established in pediatric patients
  • safety and effectiveness of extended-release tablets have not been established in pediatric patients 16 years or younger
  • equivalent doses of niacin extended-release 500-mg tablets and niacin extended-release 1000-mg tablet are interchangeable; however, equivalent doses of niacin extended-release 500-mg tablets and niacin extended-release 750-mg tablets are not interchangeable
  • Dyslipidemia, Mixed - Primary hypercholesterolemia: (older than 16 years; extended-release) initial, 500 mg ORALLY once daily at bedtime; titrate in 500-mg intervals every 4 weeks based on tolerability and efficacy; MAX 2000 mg/day
  • Dyslipidemia, Mixed - Primary hypercholesterolemia: (older than 16 years; extended-release) maintenance, 1000 to 2000 mg ORALLY once daily; MAX 2000 mg/day
  • Hypertriglyceridemia, severe: (older than 16 years; extended-release) initial, 500 mg ORALLY once daily at bedtime; titrate in 500-mg intervals every 4 weeks based on tolerability and efficacy; MAX 2000 mg/day
  • Hypertriglyceridemia, severe: (older than 16 years; extended-release) maintenance, 1000 to 2000 mg ORALLY once daily; MAX 2000 mg/day
  • Myocardial infarction, In patients with a history of myocardial infarction and hyperlipidemia; Prophylaxis: (older than 16 years; extended-release) initial, 500 mg ORALLY once daily at bedtime; titrate in 500-mg intervals every 4 weeks based on tolerability and efficacy; MAX 2000 mg/day
  • Myocardial infarction, In patients with a history of myocardial infarction and hyperlipidemia; Prophylaxis: (older than 16 years; extended-release) maintenance, 1000 to 2000 mg ORALLY once daily; MAX 2000 mg/day
  • Recommended dietary allowance: 0 to 6 months of age, 2 mg/day ORALLY
  • Recommended dietary allowance: 6 to 12 months of age, 4 mg/day ORALLY
  • Recommended dietary allowance: 1 to 3 years of age, 6 mg/day ORALLY
  • Recommended dietary allowance: 4 to 8 years of age, 8 mg/day ORALLY
  • Recommended dietary allowance: 9 to 13 years of age, 12 mg/day ORALLY
  • Recommended dietary allowance: 14 to 18 years of age: male, 16 mg/day ORALLY; female, 14 mg/day ORALLY

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono: Hepatic impairment, active liver disease, unexplained transaminase elevations, and significant or unexplained hepatic dysfunction: Use contraindicated

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Coronary arteriosclerosis, in combination with a bile acid binding resin - Hyperlipidemia
  • Dyslipidemia, Mixed - Primary hypercholesterolemia
  • Hypertriglyceridemia, severe
  • Myocardial infarction, In patients with a history of myocardial infarction and hyperlipidemia; Prophylaxis
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Pellagra
  • Recommended dietary allowance

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• Active liver disease or unexplained persistent elevations in hepatic transaminases
  • Active peptic ulcer
  • Arterial bleeding
  • Hypersensitivity to niacin or any component of the product

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Cardiovascular:
  • -- Unstable angina or acute phase of a myocardial infarction, especially with concomitant use of vasoactive drugs (eg, nitrates, calcium channel blockers, adrenergic blocking agents)
  • Endocrine and Metabolic:
  • -- May cause increase in fasting glucose; monitoring recommended
  • -- Increase in uric acid may occur; use with caution in patients with a predisposition to gout
  • -- Reduction in phosphorus levels may occur; monitoring recommended
  • Gastrointestinal:
  • -- History of peptic ulcer; monitoring recommended
  • Hematologic:
  • -- Increase in prothrombin time may occur, especially with concomitant use of anticoagulants; monitoring recommended
  • -- Reduction in platelet count may occur, especially with concomitant use of anticoagulants; monitoring recommended
  • Hepatic:
  • -- History of hepatobiliary disease or jaundice; monitoring recommended
  • -- May cause abnormal liver tests; monitoring recommended
  • Musculoskeletal:
  • -- Rhabdomyolysis has been reported with concomitant use with statins, with an increased risk in patients with diabetes, renal failure, or uncontrolled hypothyroidism; monitoring recommended
  • Renal:
  • -- Renal impairment; use caution

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Niacin or nicotinic acid is a B-complex vitamin that has antihyperlipidemic effects. Its precise mechanism of action is still unknown, although it may involve actions such as reduced esterification of hepatic triglycerides, decreased release of free fatty acids from adipose tissue and increased activity of lipoprotein lipase which enhances the removal of chylomicron triglyceride from the plasma. It increases high-density lipoprotein (HDL) and reduces triglycerides, total cholesterol and LDL.

0.title: Absorption
0.mono:
• Oral: 30 min to 60 min
  • Bioavailability: at least 60% to 76%
  • Effect of food: low-fat meal maximizes bioavailability

2.title: Metabolism
2.mono:
• Hepatic; extensive first-pass metabolism, conjugation
  • Major metabolite: nicotinuric acid and nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD)

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Oral
  • extended-release, immediate-release, or sustained-release niacin are not interchangeable; do not substitute
  • pretreat with aspirin or ibuprofen 30 minutes before dose to reduce severity and frequency of flushing, pruritus, and gastrointestinal distress
  • do not take on an empty stomach
  • may take at bedtime with a low-fat snack
  • do not break, crush, or chew extended-release tablets

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• Lipid panel; periodically to evaluate efficacy
  • Liver function; at baseline, every 6 to 12 weeks for first year, then periodically thereafter (about every 6 months); repeat evaluation and monitor more frequently if elevated transaminase levels occur
  • Blood glucose; frequently, especially in patients with diabetes or prone to diabetes during few months of therapy and during dose adjustment
  • Phosphorus levels, in patients at risk for hypophosphatemia; periodically
  • Prothrombin time, in patients undergoing surgery
  • Patients with a history of jaundice, hepatobiliary disease, or peptic ulcers
  • Muscle pain, tenderness, or weakness; particularly in elderly patients, patients with diabetes, renal failure, or uncontrolled hypothyroidism; particularly during the first months of therapy and during dose increases
  • Serum creatine phosphokinase (CPK) and potassium determinations; consider periodically in at risk patients and during initial therapy or dose increases

11.mono:

    • Oral Capsule, Extended Release: 125 MG, 250 MG, 500 MG

  • Nature's Blend Niacin

  • Niacor
    Oral Tablet: 500 MG
  • Niaspan
    Oral Tablet, Extended Release: 500 MG, 750 MG, 1000 MG
  • PharmAssure Niacin
    Oral Tablet: 100 MG
  • Rite Aid Niacin 500
    Oral Tablet: 500 MG
  • Rite Aid Niacin
    Oral Tablet: 100 MG, 500 MG
  • Slo-Niacin
    Oral Tablet, Extended Release: 250 MG, 500 MG, 750 MG

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
NIACIN AND RELATED AGENTS
OVERDOSE: Epigastric discomfort, sensation of warmth, chills and intermittent rash (diffuse, red, flat, and coalescent), primarily affecting scalp, face, and legs have been reported with niacin overdose. Tachycardia, nausea, vomiting and abdominal pain have been reported. Lactic acidosis has been occurred after acute overdoses with sustained release products. Severe hypotension has been reported following a massive niacin overdose (11,000 milligrams). Elevated hepatic enzymes have developed following overdose. Laboratory findings have also included hypo- and hyperglycemia and coagulopathy in some exposures. A teenager developed a prolonged QTc interval after ingesting 5.5 grams of niacin. ADVERSE EVENTS: Flushing, pruritus, and gastrointestinal distress are frequent symptoms after oral niacin therapy. Other adverse effects include dizziness, tachycardia, palpitations, shortness of breath, sweating, chills, edema, syncope, dryness of the skin, abdominal pain, diarrhea, nausea and vomiting, anorexia, stimulation of peptic ulcer, amblyopia, jaundice and elevated hepatic enzymes, decrease in glucose tolerance, hyperglycemia, and hyperuricemia. Significant toxicity has been reported in a small number of patients following the use of niacin to interfere with urine drug screening.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
NIACIN AND RELATED AGENTS
  • Support: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive.
  • Decontamination: Gastrointestinal decontamination is generally not required after acute overdose of immediate release products. Consider activated charcoal after an acute ingestion of more than 5 g of sustained release niacin and if the patient is able to maintain airway or if airway is protected
  • Hypotensive episode: IV 0.9% NaCl at 10 mL to 20 mL/kg, dopamine, norepinephrine.
  • Monitoring of patient: Monitor vital signs, especially blood pressure. Monitor, liver enzymes, as well as fluid, electrolyte, and acid-base status in patients with significant vomiting and/or diarrhea.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
NIACIN AND RELATED AGENTS
TOXICITY: A minimum toxic dose has not been established. After ingesting 11,000 mg of niacin within a 12-hour period, a 56-year-old man developed severe, persistent hypotension (BP 58/40 mmHg) in the absence of cutaneous flushing. Following supportive therapy, he recovered completely. A 16-year-old girl developed epigastric discomfort and rash after taking 330 mg of niacin daily (more than 25 times the recommended daily allowance for a teenager). Symptoms resolved upon discontinuation of therapy. Two teenagers developed hepatotoxicity and acidosis after ingestion of 5 and 6 g of sustained-release niacin over a 48-hour period. THERAPEUTIC: ADULT: EXTENDED RELEASE FORMULATION: Initial, 500 mg orally once daily at bedtime for 4 weeks, then 1000 mg at bedtime for 4 weeks; titrate by tolerability and efficacy but no faster than 500 mg every 4 weeks; usual maintenance dose, 1000 to 2000 mg once daily at bedtime; MAX 2000 mg/day. ADULT: IMMEDIATE RELEASE FORMULATION: Initial 100 mg 3 times/day, increase to 1000 mg 3 times/day, MAX 4500 mg/day. PEDIATRIC: IMMEDIATE RELEASE: Initial, 100-250 mg/day in 3 divided doses with meals; increase 100 mg/day weekly or 250 mg/day every 2-3 wk as tolerated; MAX 10 mg/kg/day.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• This drug may cause facial flushing, pruritus, gastrointestinal irritation, nausea, or vomiting.
  • If medically approved, instruct patient to pretreat with aspirin or an NSAID 30 min before dose to reduce severity/frequency of flushing, pruritus, and gastrointestinal distress.
  • Patient should take at bedtime with a low-fat snack.
  • Patient should avoid concomitant use of anticoagulants or dilators.
  • Advise patient to limit alcohol consumption during drug therapy.
  • Instruct patient to notify healthcare professional if dose is missed for several days, as dose may require adjustment when medication resumed.
